column6: If kin are not close, their wills\nGrate like teeth in an uneven bite.
Trusting ties of flesh and blood,\nTo meet their goals they rely on kin.
The mulberry fly abandons its young.\nThe wasp that takes them on\nDoes not meet with disgrace.
Guests feel like kin in sharing rites\nWhen food and drink are properly measured.
Slighting those who deserve his care,\nHis closest friends shall run away.
Caring for those who deserve it,\nThe noble man grasps the Dipper.
However high and lofty his rank,\nHe is base in conducting affairs.
Dried meat shared with close kin:\nFlawlessly the noble man performs his duty\nTo act as trunk of the family tree.
Immature yet close: ill-omened.
Small taxes kept the same.\nHelp the common people feel secure\nAnd rectify the state.
Greedy hoarding, bit by bit,\nSteeps us in impropriety.
Seeing it is small, he eschews its use\nSo that we may fully develop.
In gathering profit and reducing punishment,\nSmall is the advance and great the retreat.
Livestock propagate contentedly,\nSnowy white cocoons blanket the fields.
Though small and weak at first,\nSomething big begins to grow.\nThe petty man fails to take heed.

The husband pulls in the cart shafts.
His wife peels wild and bitter herbs.
What benefits the king's paternal aunts
Does nothing for the common run of men.
An affliction.
Heavy taxes bring down the state.
Taxing in season\nHelps forestall utter ruin.
To be hardheaded is not right.\nIt makes him utterly useless.
The phoenix spreads its wings in flight.\nNoble men approach the proper time:\nNo one can ever hold them back.
If pillars are uncentered and beams not high,\nThe great mansion is laid low.
Keen of eye and ear, there and over there,\nHis attendants, left and right,\nOffer him staunch support.
Noble men, when strong, use virtue.\nPetty men, when strong, use force.
Using my strength to "overcome myself,"\nThe sky is the limit to what I can do.
Metal is strong but flesh is weak.\nBlood flows in the fields.
He strengthens where he fails,\nMaking an effort where he is weak.
He uproots Mount T'ai,\nHe snaps pillars and beams.\nSuch men stumble and fall.
Pure within,\nHe is clear, without stain.
Tainted secretly, while feigning purity,\nHe is ashamed to the center of his self.
He lifts his eyes up to Heaven.\nHe lowers his ears to the depths.\nSuch is reverence.
The petty man envies the pure,\nAnd so looses rank and propriety.
Pure to the hidden "yellow" core:\nSupremely stable, he knows no bounds.
Great purity gives way to error,\nAnd so there is change.
In his purity, he sees his faults in time.\nThe noble man moves to repair them.
Pure evil, without a trace of good.
Pure to the end and forever new,\nHe is propriety exemplified.
